awd_titl_txt: Leveraging Data Communities to Advance Open Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop will advance scientific community readiness to share dataset metadata and create evidence-based practices to maximize the impact of that sharing. The workshop will do this by addressing the need for focused collaboration between scientists and information and technology professionals to understand, support, and promote the growth of “data communities,” formal or informal networks of scientists who voluntarily share and reuse a particular type of data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This award funded a virtual incubation workshop series that brought together scientific research teams from a wide range of fields to develop actionable strategies to advance voluntary data sharing and reuse using a ?data communities? framework. Data communities are fluid networks of scientists who voluntarily exchange and reuse data across disciplinary boundaries to advance shared or complementary research goals, often organized around a domain repository. The data communities framework emphasizes that social, cultural, and interpersonal relationships are an important aspect of successful data sharing initiatives and seeks to leverage the incentives, motivations of researchers with overlapping research agendas and, often, professional connections, to increase the quantity and quality of data being shared. 

 

At the workshop, fourteen research teams representing both nascent and established data communities were matched with an information professional with expertise in specific data management and curation challenges they faced. Participants met primarily in small groups to consider solutions to technical challenges and develop strategies for growing the active user base of repositories by conceptualizing their repository as a hub for a data community. Participants focused particular attention on the intersection of the technical infrastructures and cultural infrastructures that enable and encourage robust data sharing.

Key findings from the workshop include the following:

  • Data communities have distinct support needs at different points in their life cycle, but all data communities will benefit from treating their social infrastructure as a vital ingredient in successful data sharing efforts.

  • Bringing together researchers from radically different disciplines and dedicated information professionals for conversations about data sharing challenges can provide opportunities to discern strategies for data sharing that cut across disciplines and fields.

  • Domain repositories offer unique advantages for promoting social and cultural aspects of data sharing. However, both domain and generalist repositories will benefit from greater connections across platforms that will advance discoverability.

Following the workshop, the primary investigators published a public report detailing key findings and exploring opportunities and challenges associated with building active data sharing communities between researchers from different fields and approaches to overlapping research areas, specific support needs faced by data communities and domain repositories across their life cycle, and approaches to developing metadata to allow sharing across domain and generalists repositories through the NSF?s public access repository. The workshop also resulted in a series of actionable recommendations for researchers, information professionals, universities, funders, and repositories about how the data community framework can advance the goals of open science.


 

 


Last Modified: 12/09/2022
Modified by: Danielle Cooper
